o improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Sun Pacific Ducor's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Sun Pacific Ducor's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Sun Pacific Ducor has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Sun Pacific Ducor has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Sun Pacific Ducor now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Sun Pacific Ducor employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Sun Pacific Ducor will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Sun Pacific Ducor has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 Sun Pacific Ducor, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Sun Pacific Ducor has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name           | Process Chemical           | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Ammonia Refrigeration    Anhydrous Ammonia            30,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2.

Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Description

Facility Layout

Sun Pacific Ducor operates a commercial cold storage/food processing plant for table grapes in Ducor, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:
 
(11) Rooms
(2) Precool Rooms
(1) Hallway
(1) Shipping Dock
 
Refrigeration System Equipment

The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Sun Pacific Ducor has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Sun Pacific Ducor facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year.It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active records of all p

rocedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

Sun Pacific Ducor has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Sun Pacific Ducor's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR §1910.38
- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR §5189(n)
- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR §1910.119(n)
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 §2765.1-2765.2
- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR §68.95
- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 §2731

Strategically, we will respond minimally to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
